Vocabulary from the Magna Carta on its 8.list_detailed_description: The Magna Carta, signed in 1215, is 800 years old on June 15, 2015. The Magna Carta settled the rebellion of some barons against the king. Although some of the language is still obscure, the document is widely credited as being the first statement of individual rights under kingly rule. Among other things, it put a limit on payments that could be made to a king and ensured swift justice, guaranteed by a board of peers, in this case 25 barons. Here are 35 words from the English translation of the original Latin of this document that is the forerunner of democratic expressions like the Declaration of Independence.

Declaration of the Rights of Man (1789).list_detailed_description: Coauthored by Thomas Jefferson and General Lafayette, this declaration was approved by the National Assembly of France in 1789. Unlike the American Declaration of Independence, its content consists more of philosophical principles rather than specific grievances against an abusive king. But similarly, it led to a revolution that inspired the hearts of individuals around the world. Read this list aloud to hear the echoes that unite humanity.

\"The Declaration of Independence\" (177.list_detailed_description: The Declaration of Independence was adopted on July 4, 1776 by the Second Continental Congress in Philadelphia. Drafted by Thomas Jefferson, with a preamble by John Adams and editing by Benjamin Franklin and other members of Congress, it outlines the offenses of King George III to justify the vote for independence that had taken place two days earlier. With the colonies already one year into a war, the Declaration closed the door on reconciliation with Great Britain, paved the way for the creation of the United States of America, and continues to serve as an inspiration throughout the world.

The Universal Declaration of Human Right.list_detailed_description: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by the UN General Assembly on December 10, 1948 to reflect the commitment of the international community to prevent any repeat of the atrocities of World War II. Drafted by the Commission on Human Rights, which consisted of 18 members from various political, cultural, and religious backgrounds, it recognizes the value and rights of every individual everywhere. In addition to influencing many subsequent national constitutions, laws, and treaties, it serves as a tool to apply moral pressure on abusive governments.

Vocabulary from The Articles of Confeder.list_detailed_description: Just as "history is written by the winners," the historical record often skips over missteps or mistakes made by those same winners. The Articles of Confederation were the founding fathers' first attempt at establishing an central alliance of all the different states in 1777. Although a valiant effort, the provisions laid down in this document didn't quite work the way the writers wanted them to, and they soon realized they had to start again with a new document. That second try is known as The Constitution, and it endures to this day. Here are 43 vocabulary words from The Articles of Confederation. The entire document is available

Declaration of the Rights of Woman (1791.list_detailed_description: The full title of this declaration includes a focus on citizenship, and it was published two years after the declaration of rights for men and immediately after the National Assembly of France rejected a proposal to extend the rights to women. With an ironic tone, the writer and activist Olympe de Gouges dedicated it to Marie Antoinette, who -- as a woman -- was not seen as an equal. And, as a queen, she did nothing to promote gender equality (yet she was eventually given a trial and death sentence equal to that of King Louis XVI). While a postscript and form for a social contract are also included, the main structure and contents of this declaration parallel and parody its male counterpart. Compare these lists to hear the echoes.

The Emancipation Proclamation (1862).list_detailed_description: The pivotal document of the Civil War, this proclamation freed the slaves and opened a new chapter in the nation's history. To emancipate means to liberate or free someone. The Emancipation Proclamation was a presidential order made by Abraham Lincoln on September 22, 1862. It was a military order that freed any slave held in the Confederacy as of January 1, 1863. While this proclaimed slaves in the South free, it did not end all slavery in the United States. That was accomplished by the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution ratified In 1865.

impropriety.word_example: Resolved, that the objection of indelicacy and  impropriety, which is so often brought against woman when she addresses a public audience, comes with a very ill grace from those who encourage, by their attendance, her appearance on the stage, in the concert, or in feats of the circus.

remuneration.word_example: He has monopolized nearly all the profitable employments, and from those she is permitted to follow, she receives but a scanty  remuneration.
remuneration.word_definition: paying for goods or services or to recompense for losses

usurpation.word_definition: entry to another's property without right or permission

supposition.word_example: He has so framed the laws of divorce, as to what shall be the proper causes and, in case of separation, to whom the guardianship of the children shall be given, as to be wholly regardless of the happiness of the women—the law, in all cases, going upon a false  supposition of the supremacy of man and giving all power into his hands.
supposition.word_definition: a hypothesis that is taken for granted

precept.word_example: Resolved, That such laws as conflict, in any way, with the true and substantial happiness of woman, are contrary to the great  precept of nature and of no validity, for this is "superior in obligation to any other."

facility.word_example: He has denied her the  facilities for obtaining a thorough education, all colleges being closed against her.
facility.word_definition: a building or place that provides a particular service

circumscribe.word_example: Resolved, that woman has too long rested satisfied in the  circumscribed limits which corrupt customs and a perverted application of the Scriptures have marked out for her, and that it is time she should move in the enlarged sphere which her great Creator has assigned her.

endeavor.word_example: We shall employ agents, circulate tracts, petition the state and national legislatures, and  endeavor to enlist the pulpit and the press in our behalf.

conscience.word_example: Resolved, that all laws which prevent woman from occupying such a station in society as her  conscience shall dictate, or which place her in a position inferior to that of man, are contrary to the great precept of nature and therefore of no force or authority.
conscience.word_definition: motivation deriving from ethical or moral principles

capability.word_example: Resolved, that the equality of human rights results necessarily from the fact of the identity of the race in  capabilities and responsibilities.
capability.word_definition: the quality of being able to do something

sentiment.word_example: He has created a false public  sentiment by giving to the world a different code of morals for men and women, by which moral delinquencies which exclude women from society are not only tolerated but deemed of little account in man.

adverse.word_example: and this being a self-evident truth growing out of the divinely implanted principles of human nature, any custom or authority  adverse to it, whether modern or wearing the hoary sanction of antiquity, is to be regarded as a self-evident falsehood, and at war with mankind.

prerogative.word_definition: a right reserved exclusively by a person or group

compel.word_example: He has  compelled her to submit to law in the formation of which she had no voice.

impunity.word_example: He has made her morally, an irresponsible being, as she can commit many crimes with  impunity, provided they be done in the presence of her husband.

inalienable.word_example: We hold these truths to be self-evident: that all men and women are created equal; that they are endowed by their Creator with certain  inalienable rights; that among these are life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness; that to secure these rights governments are instituted, deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed.

\"The Declaration of Sentiments\" (1848).list_detailed_description: The Declaration of Sentiments was presented in July 1848 at the first Women's Rights Convention in Seneca Falls. Composed by the abolitionist Elizabeth Cady Stanton, it deliberately echoes the Declaration of Independence by casting women in the role of the oppressed and men in the role of the tyrant. This led to much heated dispute, but it is now recognized as the first step towards the addition of the 19th Amendment to the US Constitution.

The Dred Scott Decision (1857).list_detailed_description: Vocabulary from this pro-slavery Supreme Court decision illuminates how it brought the nation to the brink of the Civil War. In March of 1857, Chief Justice Roger B. Taney delivered the majority opinion in the Dred Scott Case. Scott, a slave, had been brought from a slave territory to a free territory and demanded his freedom. The Court ruled that as a slave, Scott was not a citizen and as such could not sue in the courts. The decision further polarized the North and the South and ended any chance of compromise on the issue of slavery.

Christopher Columbus: The First Voyage.list_detailed_description: Christopher Columbus embarked on the first of three voyages to the "New World" with three ships — the Niña, Pinta and Santa María — on August 3, 1492. He kept a logbook in which he faked some entries to soothe a mutinous crew, and a private diary in which he detailed the details of the journey that shaped the subsequent history of the western hemisphere. Upon his return to Spain, Columbus presented his record to Queen Isabella I of Castile. She had it copied and retained the original, then gave the copy to Columbus before his second voyage. The whereabouts of the original Spanish text remain a mystery — its location has not been known since 1504. Here are 14 words selected from the historic text.

council.word_definition: an assembly convened to regulate matters of doctrine

measure.word_example: The Mohawk Lords are the foundation of the Great Peace and it shall, therefore, be against the Great Binding Law to pass  measures in the Confederate Council after the Mohawk Lords have protested against them.
measure.word_definition: a statute in draft before it becomes law

establish.word_example: A large bunch of shell strings, in the making of which the Five Nations Confederate Lords have equally contributed, shall symbolize the completeness of the union and certify the pledge of the nations represented by the Confederate Lords of the Mohawk, the Oneida, the Onondaga, the Cayuga and the Senecca, that all are united and formed into one body or union called the Union of the Great Law, which they have  established.

compact.word_example: Whenever a foreign nation enters the Confederacy or accepts the Great Peace, the Five Nations and the foreign nation shall enter into an agreement and  compact by which the foreign nation shall endeavor to persuade other nations to accept the Great Peace.

jurisdiction.word_definition: the territory within which power can be exercised

ineligible.word_example: Certain physical defects in a Confederate Lord make him  ineligible to sit in the Confederate Council. Such defects are infancy, idiocy, blindness, deafness, dumbness and impotency.
ineligible.word_definition: not qualified for or allowed or worthy of being chosen

sufficient.word_example: Then shall Adodarhoh call his cousin (associate) Lords together and consider whether or not the case is of  sufficient importance to demand the attention of the Confederate Council.
sufficient.word_definition: of a quantity that can fulfill a need or requirement

prescribe.word_example: If either a nephew or a niece see an irregularity in the performance of the functions of the Great Peace and its laws, in the Confederate Council or in the conferring of Lordship titles in an improper way, through their War Chief they may demand that such actions become subject to correction and that the matter conform to the ways  prescribed by the laws of the Great Peace.

qualified.word_example: If a Lord dies and there is no candidate  qualified for the office in the family of the women title holders, the Lords of the Nation shall give the title into the hands of a sister family in the clan until such a time as the original family produces a candidate, when the title shall be restored to the rightful owners.
qualified.word_definition: meeting the proper standards and requirements for a task

declaration.word_example: When the Confederate Council of the Five Nations has for its object the establishment of the Great Peace among the people of an outside nation and that nation refuses to accept the Great Peace, then by such refusal they bring a  declaration of war upon themselves from the Five Nations.

assemble.word_example: When the Lords are  assembled the Council Fire shall be kindled, but not with chestnut wood, and Adodarhoh shall formally open the Council.

provision.word_example: If a War Chief acts contrary to instructions or against the  provisions of the Laws of the Great Peace, doing so in the capacity of his office, he shall be deposed by his women relatives and by his men relatives.

behalf.word_example: When the Lords of the Confederacy take occasion to dispatch a messenger in  behalf of the Confederate Council, they shall wrap up any matter they may send and instruct the messenger to remember his errand, to turn not aside but to proceed faithfully to his destination and deliver his message according to every instruction.
behalf.word_definition: as the agent of or on someone's part

legal.word_example: No council of the Confederate Lords shall be  legal unless all the Mohawk Lords are present.
legal.word_definition: having efficacy or force under law

appoint.word_example: I, Dekanawidah,  appoint the Mohawk Lords the heads and the leaders of the Five Nations Confederacy.
appoint.word_definition: assign a duty, responsibility or obligation to

nominate.word_example: A Lord in proposing to resign may recommend any proper candidate which recommendation shall be received by the Lords, but unless confirmed and  nominated by the women who hold the title the candidate so named shall not be considered.
nominate.word_definition: propose as a candidate for some honor

deliberate.word_example: He may only  deliberate in a low tone with the separate body of which he is a member.
deliberate.word_definition: discuss the pros and cons of an issue

summon.word_example: If so, Adodarhoh shall dispatch messengers to  summon all the Confederate Lords to assemble beneath the Tree of the Long Leaves.
summon.word_definition: call in an official matter, such as to attend court

proposition.word_example: It shall ever be his duty to lay the cases, questions and  propositions of the people before the Confederate Council.
proposition.word_definition: a suggestion offered for acceptance or rejection

unanimous.word_example: In all cases the procedure must be as follows: when the Mohawk and Seneca Lords have unanimously agreed upon a question, they shall report their decision to the Cayuga and Oneida Lords who shall deliberate upon the question and report a  unanimous decision to the Mohawk Lords.

mentor.word_example: It shall be the duty of all of the Five Nations Confederate Lords, from time to time as occasion demands, to act as  mentors and spiritual guides of their people and remind them of their Creator's will and words.
mentor.word_definition: a wise and trusted guide and advisor

treason.word_example: If a nation, part of a nation, or more than one nation within the Five Nations should in any way endeavor to destroy the Great Peace by neglect or violating its laws and resolve to dissolve the Confederacy, such a nation or such nations shall be deemed guilty of  treason and called enemies of the Confederacy and the Great Peace.
treason.word_definition: a crime that undermines the offender's government

entitled.word_example: Every person not  entitled to enter the house by right of living within it upon seeing such a sign shall not approach the house either by day or by night but shall keep as far away as his business will permit.
entitled.word_definition: qualified for by right according to law

dissolve.word_example: Every five years the Five Nations Confederate Lords and the people shall assemble together and shall ask one another if their minds are still in the same spirit of unity for the Great Binding Law and if any of the Five Nations shall not pledge continuance and steadfastness to the pledge of unity then the Great Binding Law shall  dissolve.
dissolve.word_definition: stop functioning or cohering as a unit

Iroquois Constitution.list_detailed_description: Also known as The Great Binding Law, this document established a representative confederacy of five tribes: Mohawk, Oneida, Seneca, Cuyuga, and Onondaga. Its exact date is uncertain (possible years are 1142, 1451, and 1525), but many historians agree that it is the first constitution in the New World.

Lee Surrenders to Grant (1865).list_brief_description: On April 9, 1865, after a final battle that failed to break through Union forces, Robert E. Lee surrendered at the Appomattox Court House in Virginia. As a brig...

cordial.word_example: They all stepped up to pay their respects to General Grant, who received them very cordially and talked with them until it was time to leave.

humiliation.word_example: Then he looked toward Lee, and his eyes seemed to be resting on the handsome sword that hung at that officer's side. He said afterward that this set him to thinking that it would be an unnecessary  humiliation to require the officers to surrender their swords
humiliation.word_definition: an instance causing you to lose prestige or self-respect

improvise.word_example: Then was witnessed one of the most inspiring scenes of the campaign. Bonfires were lighted on the sides of the street, the men seized straw and pine knots, and  improvised torches; cheers arose from throats already hoarse with shouts of victory, bands played, banners waved, arms were tossed high in air and caught again.
improvise.word_definition: manage in a makeshift way; do with whatever is at hand

overwhelm.word_example: All appreciated the sadness that  overwhelmed him, and he had the personal sympathy of every one who beheld him at this supreme moment of trial.
overwhelm.word_definition: overcome, as with emotions or perceptual stimuli

apprehensive.word_example: After reading it, the general rose and said he would ride forward on the road on which Babcock had come, but was  apprehensive that hostilities might begin in the meantime, upon the termination of the temporary truce, and asked Babcock to write a line to Meade informing him of the situation.
apprehensive.word_definition: in fear or dread of possible evil or harm

stipulation.word_example: I will proceed to designate the proper officers to carry the  stipulations into effect.
stipulation.word_definition: an agreement made by parties in a judicial proceeding

remnant.word_example: The charges were now withdrawn from the guns, the camp-fires were left to smolder in their ashes, the flags were tenderly furled--those historic banners, battle-stained, bullet-riddled, many of them but  remnants of their former selves, with scarcely enough left of them on which to imprint the names of the battles they had seen--and the Army of the Union and the Army of Northern Virginia turned their backs upon each other for the first time in four long, bloody years.
remnant.word_definition: a small part remaining after the main part no longer exists

genteel.word_example: We asked Colonel Marshall afterward how it was that both he and his chief wore such fine toggery, and looked so much as if they had turned out to go to church, while with us our outward garb scarcely rose to the dignity even of the "shabby- genteel."
genteel.word_definition: marked by refinement in taste and manners

substantially.word_example: General Grant replied: "The terms I propose are those stated  substantially in my letter of yesterday--that is, the officers and men surrendered to be paroled and disqualified from taking up arms again until properly exchanged, and all arms, ammunition, and supplies to be delivered up as captured property."
substantially.word_definition: to a great extent or degree

inculcate.word_example: About 9 o'clock on the morning of the 10th General Grant with his staff rode out toward the enemy's lines, but it was found upon attempting to pass through that the force of habit is hard to overcome, and that the practice which had so long been  inculcated in Lee's army of keeping Grant out of his lines was not to be overturned in a day, and he was politely requested at the picket-lines to wait till a message could be sent to headquarters asking for instructions.
inculcate.word_definition: teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions

propitiate.word_example: He enlightened us regarding the contrast, by explaining that when their headquarters wagons had been pressed so closely by our cavalry a few days before, and it was found they would have to destroy all their baggage, except the clothes they carried on their backs, each one, naturally, selected the newest suit he had, and sought to  propitiate the god of destruction by a sacrifice of his second best.

surmise.word_example: What was passing in his mind probably no one ever knew, but the natural  surmise was that he at first mistook Parker for a Negro, and was struck with astonishment to find that the commander of the Union armies had one of that race on his personal staff.
surmise.word_definition: a message expressing an opinion based on incomplete evidence

rejoice.word_example: "The war is over, the rebels are our countrymen again, and the best sign of  rejoicing after the victory will be to abstain from all demonstrations in the field."

inadvertently.word_example: "I presumed it had been omitted  inadvertently," continued Lee, "and with your permission I will mark where it should be inserted."

sentiment.word_example: Finding that he entertained these  sentiments, General Grant told him that no one's influence in the South was so great as his, and suggested to him that he should advise the surrender of the remaining armies and thus exert his influence in favor of immediate peace.

conciliate.word_example: It will be very gratifying and will do much toward  conciliating our people.
conciliate.word_definition: gain the good will of or cause to be more favorably inclined

erect.word_example: Lee, on the other hand, was fully six feet in height, and quite  erect for one of his age, for he was Grant's senior by sixteen years.

allude.word_example: It was doubtless the condition mentioned to which he particularly  alluded when he looked toward General Grant as he finished reading and said with some degree of warmth in his manner: "This will have a very happy effect upon my army."

reciprocate.word_example: GENERAL: I have received your note of this date. Though not entertaining the opinion you express of the hopelessness of further resistance on the part of the Army of Northern Virginia, I  reciprocate your desire to avoid useless effusion of blood, and therefore, before considering your proposition, ask the terms you will offer on condition of its surrender.
reciprocate.word_definition: act, feel, or give mutually or in return

swarthy.word_example: Parker was a full-blooded Indian, and the reigning Chief of the Six Nations. When Lee saw his  swarthy features he looked at him with evident surprise, and his eyes rested on him for several seconds.
swarthy.word_definition: naturally having skin of a dark color

scant.word_example: General Grant had been suffering all the afternoon from a severe headache, the result of fatigue, anxiety,  scant fare, and loss of sleep, and by night it was much worse.
scant.word_definition: less than the correct or legal or full amount

contrast.word_example: The  contrast between the two commanders was striking, and could not fail to attract marked attention as they sat ten feet apart facing each other.
contrast.word_definition: the opposition or dissimilarity of things that are compared

correspondence.word_example: A little before noon on the 7th of April, 1865, General Grant, with his staff, rode into the little village of Farmville, on the south side of the Appomattox River, a town that will be memorable in history as the place where he opened the  correspondence with Lee which led to the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia.
correspondence.word_definition: communication by the exchange of letters

accord.word_example: Lee inclined his head as indicating his  accord with this wish, and General Grant then went on to talk at some length in a very pleasant vein about the prospects of peace.

provisions.word_example: This statement, together with the news that had been received from Sheridan saying that he had heard that General Lee's trains of  provisions which had come by rail were at Appomattox, and that he expected to capture them before Lee could reach them, induced the general to write the following communication:
provisions.word_definition: a stock or supply of foods

reverie.word_example: The approach of his horse seemed to recall him from his  reverie, and he at once mounted.

countenance.word_example: When Lee came to the sentence about the officers' side-arms, private horses, and baggage, he showed for the first time during the reading of the letter a slight change of  countenance, and was evidently touched by this act of generosity.
countenance.word_definition: the appearance conveyed by a person's face

bridle.word_example: Lee signaled to his orderly to bring up his horse, and while the animal was being  bridled the general stood on the lowest step and gazed sadly in the direction of the valley beyond where his army lay--now an army of prisoners.
bridle.word_definition: the act of restraining power or action or limiting excess

effusion.word_example: The results of the last week must convince you of the hopelessness of further resistance on the part of the Army of Northern Virginia in this struggle. I feel that it is so, and regard it as my duty to shift from myself the responsibility of any further  effusion of blood by asking of you the surrender of that portion of the Confederate States army known as the Army of Northern Virginia.

conspicuous.word_example: The road was filled with men, animals, and wagons, and to avoid these and shorten the distance we turned slightly to the right and began to "cut across lots"; but before going far we spied men  conspicuous in gray, and it was seen that we were moving toward the enemy's left flank, and that a short ride farther would take us into his lines.
conspicuous.word_definition: obvious to the eye or mind

toilsome.word_example: Notwithstanding their long march that day, the men sprang to their feet with a spirit that made every one marvel at their pluck, and came swinging through the main street of the village with a step that seemed as elastic as on the first day of their  toilsome tramp.
toilsome.word_definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion

conviction.word_example: "The cavalrymen and artillerists own their own horses in our army. Its organization in this respect differs from that of the United States." This expression attracted the notice of our officers present, as showing how firmly the  conviction was grounded in his mind that we were two distinct countries.
conviction.word_definition: an unshakable belief in something without need for proof

commodious.word_example: McLean ushered them into the sitting-room of one of the first houses he came to, but upon looking about and finding it quite small and meagerly furnished, Lee proposed finding something more  commodious and better fitted for the occasion.

averse.word_example: Lee, however, was  averse to stepping beyond his duties as a soldier, and said the authorities would doubtless soon arrive at the same conclusion without his interference.

hindrance.word_example: He said the emancipation of the Negroes would be no  hindrance to the restoring of relations between the two sections of the country, as it would probably not be the desire of the majority of the Southern people to restore slavery then, even if the question were left open to them.
hindrance.word_definition: something immaterial that interferes with action or progress

jocose.word_example: Williams at one time referred in rather  jocose a manner to a circumstance which occurred during their former service together, as if he wanted to say something in a good natured way to break up the frigidity of the conversation, but Lee was in no mood for pleasantries, and he did not unbend, or even relax the fixed sternness of his features.
jocose.word_definition: characterized by jokes and good humor

concession.word_example: His face showed plainly that he was quite anxious to have this  concession made, and Grant said very promptly and without giving Lee time to make a direct request.

distinguished.word_example: As soon as Lee heard that his  distinguished opponent was approaching, he was prompt to correct the misunderstanding at the picket-line, and rode out at a gallop to receive him.
distinguished.word_definition: standing above others in character or attainment

Lee Surrenders to Grant (1865).list_detailed_description: On April 9, 1865, after a final battle that failed to break through Union forces, Robert E. Lee surrendered at the Appomattox Court House in Virginia. As a brigadier general and secretary to Ulysses S. Grant, Horace Porter witnessed and recorded this event. In his report, Porter included detailed observations, letters between the opposing generals, and personal opinions—all of which served to emphasize the humanity of the moments leading up to and surrounding the formal ceremony that is now seen as the end of the Civil War.

\"Common Sense,\" Vocabulary from the pa.list_brief_description: As you read Thomas Paine's “Common Sense” (etext found here), learn this word list of 50 words.

ruffian.word_example: This is supposing the present race of kings in the world to have had an honourable origin; whereas it is more than probable, that could we take off the dark covering of antiquities, and trace them to their first rise, that we should find the first of them nothing better than the principal  ruffian of some restless gang, whose savage manners or preeminence in subtlety obtained the title of chief among plunderers

insolent.word_example: Men who look upon themselves born to reign, and others to obey, soon grow  insolent; selected from the rest of mankind their minds are early poisoned by importance; and the world they act in differs so materially from the world at large, that they have but little opportunity of knowing its true interests, and when they succeed to the government are frequently the most ignorant and unfit of any throughout the dominions.

subdue.word_example: Common sense will tell us, that the power which hath endeavoured to  subdue us, is of all others the most improper to defend us.
subdue.word_definition: put down by force or intimidation

miscreant.word_example: In both these cases the public becomes a prey to every  miscreant, who can tamper successfully with the follies either of age or infancy.

expeditiously.word_example: TO CONCLUDE, however strange it may appear to some, or however unwilling they may be to think so, matters not, but many strong and striking reasons may be given, to shew, that nothing can settle our affairs so  expeditiously as an open and determined declaration for independance.
expeditiously.word_definition: with efficiency; in an efficient manner

confound.word_example: Some writers have so  confounded society with government, as to leave little or no distinction between them; whereas they are not only different, but have different origins.

extirpate.word_example: The laying a Country desolate with Fire and Sword, declaring War against the natural rights of all Mankind, and  extirpating the Defenders thereof from the Face of the Earth, is the Concern of every Man to whom Nature hath given the Power of feeling
extirpate.word_definition: destroy completely, as if down to the roots

formidable.word_example: Perhaps the sentiments contained in the following pages, are not YET sufficiently fashionable to procure them general favour; a long habit of not thinking a thing WRONG, gives it a superficial appearance of being RIGHT, and raises at first a  formidable outcry in defense of custom.
formidable.word_definition: extremely impressive in strength or excellence

inveterate.word_example: And as he hath shewn himself such an  inveterate enemy to liberty, and discovered such a thirst for arbitrary power; is he, or is he not, a proper man to say to these colonies, "YOU SHALL MAKE NO LAWS BUT WHAT I PLEASE."
inveterate.word_definition: in a habitual and longstanding manner

reconciliation.word_example: As much hath been said of the advantages of  reconciliation which, like an agreeable dream, hath passed away and left us as we were, it is but right, that we should examine the contrary side of the argument, and inquire into some of the many material injuries which these colonies sustain, and always will sustain, by being connected with, and dependent on Great Britain

imposition.word_example: To the evil of monarchy we have added that of hereditary succession; and as the first is a degradation and lessening of ourselves, so the second, claimed as a matter of right, is an insult and an  imposition on posterity.

renounce.word_example: But the injuries and disadvantages we sustain by that connection, are without number; and our duty to mankind at large, as well as to ourselves, instruct us to  renounce the alliance: Because, any submission to, or dependence on Great Britain, tends directly to involve this continent in European wars and quarrels; and sets us at variance with nations, who would otherwise seek our friendship, and against whom, we have neither anger nor complaint.

pecuniary.word_example: Besides, the taking up arms, merely to enforce the repeal of a  pecuniary law, seems as unwarrantable by the divine law, and as repugnant to human feelings, as the taking up arms to enforce obedience thereto.

prerogative.word_example: And when a man seriously reflects on the idolatrous homage which is paid to the persons of kings, he need not wonder that the Almighty, ever jealous of his honour, should disapprove of a form of government which so impiously invades the  prerogative of heaven.
prerogative.word_definition: a right reserved exclusively by a person or group

perpetually.word_example: Small islands not capable of protecting themselves, are the proper objects for kingdoms to take under their care; but there is something very absurd, in supposing a continent to be  perpetually governed by an island.

exalt.word_example: As the  exalting one man so greatly above the rest cannot be justified on the equal rights of nature, so neither can it be defended on the authority of scripture; for the will of the Almighty, as declared by Gideon and the prophet Samuel, expressly disapproves of government by kings.
exalt.word_definition: raise in rank, character, or status

injudicious.word_example: The wise, and the worthy, need not the triumph of a pamphlet; and those whose sentiments are  injudicious, or unfriendly, will cease of themselves unless too much pains are bestowed upon their conversion.
injudicious.word_definition: lacking or showing lack of judgment or discretion; unwise

obstinate.word_example: An inquiry into the CONSTITUTIONAL ERRORS in the English form of government is at this time highly necessary; for as we are never in a proper condition of doing justice to others, while we continue under the influence of some leading partiality, so neither are we capable of doing it to ourselves while we remain fettered by any  obstinate prejudice.
obstinate.word_definition: marked by tenacious unwillingness to yield

credulous.word_example: Even brutes do not devour their young, nor savages make war upon their families; wherefore the assertion, if true, turns to her reproach; but it happens not to be true, or only partly so and the phrase PARENT or MOTHER COUNTRY hath been jesuitically adopted by the king and his parasites, with a low papistical design of gaining an unfair bias on the  credulous weakness of our minds.
credulous.word_definition: showing a lack of judgment or experience

unalterable.word_example: Wherefore, the PRESENT TIME is the TRUE TIME for establishing it. The intimacy which is contracted in infancy, and the friendship which is formed in misfortune, are, of all others, the most lasting and  unalterable.
unalterable.word_definition: remaining the same for indefinitely long times

capricious.word_example: He who takes nature for his guide is not easily beaten out of his argument, and on that ground, I answer GENERALLY—THAT INDEPENDANCE BEING A SINGLE SIMPLE LINE, CONTAINED WITHIN OURSELVES; AND RECONCILIATION, A MATTER EXCEEDINGLY PERPLEXED AND COMPLICATED, AND IN WHICH, A TREACHEROUS  CAPRICIOUS COURT IS TO INTERFERE, GIVES THE ANSWER WITHOUT A DOUBT.
capricious.word_definition: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity

repugnant.word_example: It is  repugnant to reason, to the universal order of things, to all examples from former ages, to suppose, that this continent can longer remain subject to any external power.

inducement.word_example: Another evil which attends hereditary succession is, that the throne is subject to be possessed by a minor at any age; all which time the regency, acting under the cover of a king, have every opportunity and  inducement to betray their trust.

reprobate.word_example: Sincerely wishing, that as men and christians, ye may always fully and uninterruptedly enjoy every civil and religious right; and be, in your turn, the means of securing it to others; but that the example which ye have unwisely set, of mingling religion with politics, MAY BE DISAVOWED AND  REPROBATED BY EVERY INHABITANT OF AMERICA.

contention.word_example: It is the true interest of America to steer clear of European  contentions, which she never can do, while by her dependence on Britain, she is made the make-weight in the scale of British politics.
contention.word_definition: a dispute where there is strong disagreement

equivocal.word_example: These portions of scripture are direct and positive. They admit of no  equivocal construction. That the Almighty hath here entered his protest against monarchical government, is true, or the scripture is false.
equivocal.word_definition: open to two or more interpretations

suppress.word_example: Wherefore, her own interest leads her to  suppress the growth of OURS in every case which doth not promote her advantage, or in the least interferes with it.
suppress.word_definition: to put down by force or authority

opulence.word_example: America doth not yet know what  opulence is; and although the progress which she hath made stands unparalleled in the history of other nations, it is but childhood, compared with what she would be capable of arriving at, had she, as she ought to have, the legislative powers in her own hands.
opulence.word_definition: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living

impregnable.word_example: but as nothing but heaven is  impregnable to vice, it will unavoidably happen, that in proportion as they surmount the first difficulties of emigration, which bound them together in a common cause, they will begin to relax in their duty and attachment to each other
impregnable.word_definition: incapable of being overcome, challenged, or refuted

impious.word_example: How  impious is the title of sacred majesty applied to a worm, who in the midst of his splendor is crumbling into dust!
impious.word_definition: lacking piety or reverence for a god

sycophant.word_example: But if you have, and still can shake hands with the murderers, then are you unworthy of the name of husband, father, friend, or lover, and whatever may be your rank or title in life, you have the heart of a coward, and the spirit of a  sycophant.
sycophant.word_definition: a person who tries to please someone to gain an advantage

infirmity.word_example: The same national misfortune happens, when a king, worn out with age and  infirmity, enters the last stage of human weakness.
infirmity.word_definition: the state of being weak in health or body

supersede.word_example: Thus necessity, like a gravitating power, would soon form our newly arrived emigrants into society, the reciprocal blessings of which, would  supersede, and render the obligations of law and government unnecessary while they remained perfectly just to each other
supersede.word_definition: take the place or move into the position of

plausible.word_example: The most  plausible plea, which hath ever been offered in favour of hereditary succession, is, that it preserves a nation from civil wars; and were this true, it would be weighty; whereas, it is the most barefaced falsity ever imposed upon mankind.
plausible.word_definition: apparently reasonable and valid, and truthful

farcical.word_example: To say that the constitution of England is a UNION of three powers reciprocally CHECKING each other, is  farcical, either the words have no meaning, or they are flat contradictions.

sanctify.word_example: This accounts for the continuation of monarchy; neither do the characters of the few good kings which have lived since, either  sanctify the title, or blot out the sinfulness of the origin; the high encomium given of David takes no notice of him OFFICIALLY AS A KING, but only as a MAN after God's own heart.
sanctify.word_definition: make pure or free from sin or guilt

prepossession.word_example: And as a man, who is attached to a prostitute, is unfitted to choose or judge a wife, so any  prepossession in favour of a rotten constitution of government will disable us from discerning a good one.
prepossession.word_definition: an opinion formed beforehand without adequate evidence

fallacious.word_example: I have heard it asserted by some, that as America hath flourished under her former connection with Great Britain that the same connection is necessary towards her future happiness, and will always have the same effect. Nothing can be more  fallacious than this kind of argument.
fallacious.word_definition: based on an incorrect or misleading notion or information

folly.word_example: To talk of friendship with those in whom our reason forbids us to have faith, and our affections wounded through a thousand pores instruct us to detest, is madness and  folly.

explicit.word_example: Words need not be more  explicit; Gideon doth not decline the honour, but denieth their right to give it; neither doth he compliment them with invented declarations of his thanks, but in the positive style of a prophet charges them with disaffection to their proper Sovereign, the King of heaven.
explicit.word_definition: precisely and clearly expressed or readily observable

manifest.word_example: And though they might say, "We choose you for OUR head," they could not, without  manifest injustice to their children, say, "that your children and your children's children shall reign over OURS for ever."
manifest.word_definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

timorous.word_example: Oppression is often the CONSEQUENCE, but seldom or never the MEANS of riches; and though avarice will preserve a man from being necessitously poor, it generally makes him too  timorous to be wealthy.
timorous.word_definition: timid by nature or revealing timidity

depredation.word_example: and who by increasing in power, and extending his  depredations, overawed the quiet and defenseless to purchase their safety by frequent contributions.
depredation.word_definition: an act of plundering and pillaging and marauding

expedient.word_example: That as even the best terms, which we can expect to obtain, can amount to no more than a temporary  expedient, or a kind of government by guardianship, which can last no longer than till the colonies come of age, so the general face and state of things, in the interim, will be unsettled and unpromising.

consequence.word_example: That the crown is this overbearing part in the English constitution, needs not be mentioned, and that it derives its whole  consequence merely from being the giver of places and pensions, is self-evident, wherefore, though we have been wise enough to shut and lock a door against absolute monarchy, we at the same time have been foolish enough to put the crown in possession of the key.

divest.word_example: In the following pages I offer nothing more than simple facts, plain arguments, and common sense; and have no other Preliminaries to settle with the reader, than that he will  divest himself of prejudice and prepossession, and suffer his reason and his feelings to determine for themselves
divest.word_definition: cease to hold, as an investment

intolerable.word_example: Society in every state is a blessing, but government even in its best state is but a necessary evil; in its worst state an  intolerable one; for when we suffer, or are exposed to the same miseries BY A GOVERNMENT, which we might expect in a country WITHOUT GOVERNMENT, our calamity is heightened by reflecting that we furnish the means by which we suffer.
intolerable.word_definition: incapable of being put up with

The Atlantic Charter - Churchill/Rooseve.list_brief_description: The alliance between the U.S. and the U.K. in World War II was forged by this document. Understand the words that went into it.

secure.word_example: Fifth, they desire to bring about the fullest collaboration between all nations in the economic field with the object of  securing, for all, improved labor standards, economic advancement and social security;

deprive.word_example: Third, they respect the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live; and they wish to see sovereign rights and self government restored to those who have been forcibly  deprived of them;

deem.word_example: The President of the United States of America and the Prime Minister, Mr. Churchill, representing His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom, being met together,  deem it right to make known certain common principles in the national policies of their respective countries on which they base their hopes for a better future for the world.
deem.word_definition: keep in mind or convey as a conviction or view

endeavor.word_example: Fourth, they will  endeavor, with due respect for their existing obligations, to further the enjoyment by all States, great or small, victor or vanquished, of access, on equal terms, to the trade and to the raw materials of the world which are needed for their economic prosperity;

pending.word_example: Since no future peace can be maintained if land, sea or air armaments continue to be employed by nations which threaten, or may threaten, aggression outside of their frontiers, they believe,  pending the establishment of a wider and permanent system of general security, that the disarmament of such nations is essential.

aggrandizement.word_example: First, their countries seek no  aggrandizement, territorial or other;

victor.word_example: Fourth, they will endeavor, with due respect for their existing obligations, to further the enjoyment by all States, great or small,  victor or vanquished, of access, on equal terms, to the trade and to the raw materials of the world which are needed for their economic prosperity;
victor.word_definition: a combatant who is able to defeat rivals

prosperity.word_example: Fourth, they will endeavor, with due respect for their existing obligations, to further the enjoyment by all States, great or small, victor or vanquished, of access, on equal terms, to the trade and to the raw materials of the world which are needed for their economic  prosperity;

frontier.word_definition: an international boundary or the area immediately inside it

access.word_definition: the right to make use of or take advantage of something

policy.word_definition: argument rationalizing the course of action of a government

dwell.word_example: Sixth, after the final destruction of the Nazi tyranny, they hope to see established a peace which will afford to all nations the means of dwelling in safety within their own boundaries, and which will afford assurance that all the men in all lands may live out their lives in freedom from fear and want;

accord.word_example: Second, they desire to see no territorial changes that do not  accord with the freely expressed wishes of the peoples concerned;

vanquish.word_definition: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict

Quartering Act (1765).list_detailed_description: The Quartering Act of 1765 was an act passed by British Parliament, which forced people in the US colonies to house and feed British soldiers during times of peace if there was no room in barracks. The symbolic power of this act was great, as it implied that there would now be a British standing army in the colonies during peace time. The act was largely ineffective and expired in 1767, however, it was amended in 1774 as part of the Intolerable Acts.

breadth.word_description: Dr. King is using breadth as a synonym for width.
breadth.word_example: I have traveled the length and  breadth of Alabama, Mississippi and all the other southern states.
breadth.word_definition: the extent of something from side to side

contemporary.word_example: So often the  contemporary church is a weak, ineffectual voice with an uncertain sound.
contemporary.word_definition: occurring in the same period of time

segregate.word_example: Birmingham is probably the most thoroughly  segregated city in the United States.

elegy.word_example: Now is the time to make real the promise of democracy and transform our pending national  elegy into a creative psalm of brotherhood.
elegy.word_definition: a mournful poem; a lament for the dead

devotee.word_example: But he will not see this without pressure from  devotees of civil rights.

superficial.word_example: I am sure that none of you would want to rest content with the  superficial kind of social analysis that deals merely with effects and does not grapple with underlying causes.
superficial.word_definition: only concerned with what is apparent or obvious

relegate.word_example: Segregation, to use the terminology of the Jewish philosopher Martin Buber, substitutes an "I-it" relationship for an "I-thou" relationship and ends up  relegating persons to the status of things.

latent.word_description: In psychology latent refers to something that is in the unconscious.
latent.word_example: The Negro has many pent-up resentments and  latent frustrations, and he must release them.
latent.word_definition: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized

integrate.word_example: I commend the Catholic leaders of this state for  integrating Spring Hill College several years ago.
integrate.word_definition: open up to members of all races and ethnic groups

righteousness.word_example: Was not Amos an extremist for justice: "Let justice roll down like waters and  righteousness like an ever-flowing stream."

repressed.word_definition: characterized by the suppression of impulses or emotions

congregation.word_example: But again I am thankful to God that some noble souls from the ranks of organized religion have broken loose from the paralyzing chains of conformity and joined us as active partners in the struggle for freedom, They have left their secure  congregations and walked the streets of Albany, Georgia, with us.
congregation.word_definition: a group of people who habitually attend a given church

quest.word_example: We must come to see that, as the federal courts have consistently affirmed, it is wrong to urge an individual to cease his efforts to gain his basic constitutional rights because the  quest may precipitate violence.
quest.word_definition: the act of searching for something

confined.word_description: In this case Dr. King was writing from a jail cell having been arrested for conducting what local authorities considered an illegal protest.
confined.word_example: While  confined here in the Birmingham city jail, I came across your recent statement calling my present activities "unwise and untimely."

gainsay.word_example: There can be no  gainsaying the fact that racial injustice engulfs this community.

excruciating.word_example: It was practiced superbly by the early Christians, who were willing to face hungry lions and the  excruciating pain of chopping blocks rather than submit to certain unjust laws of the Roman Empire.

immoral.word_example: Individuals may see the moral light and voluntarily give up their unjust posture; but, as Reinhold Niebuhr has reminded us, groups tend to be more  immoral than individuals.

harried.word_definition: troubled persistently, especially with petty annoyances

manifest.word_description: If something is manifest it is obvious or clear.
manifest.word_example: The yearning for freedom eventually  manifests itself, and that is what has happened to the American Negro.
manifest.word_definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

substantive.word_example: I had hoped that the white moderate would understand that the present tension in the South is a necessary phase of the transition from an obnoxious negative peace, in which the Negro passively accepted his unjust plight, to a  substantive and positive peace, in which all men will respect the dignity and worth of human personality.
substantive.word_definition: having a firm basis in reality and therefore important

monologue.word_example: Too long has our beloved Southland been bogged down in a tragic effort to live in  monologue rather than dialogue.

spiritual.word_example: I say this as a minister of the gospel, who loves the church; who was nurtured in its bosom; who has been sustained by its  spiritual blessings and who will remain true to it as long as the cord of Rio shall lengthen.
spiritual.word_definition: concerned with or affecting the soul

revolution.word_example: I am thankful, however, that some of our white brothers in the South have grasped the meaning of this social  revolution and committed themselves to it.
revolution.word_definition: a drastic and far-reaching change in ways of thinking

affluent.word_definition: having an abundant supply of money or possessions of value

anarchy.word_definition: a state of lawlessness and disorder

moratorium.word_example: On the basis of these promises, the Reverend Fred Shuttlesworth and the leaders of the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights agreed to a  moratorium on all demonstrations.

paradoxical.word_definition: seemingly contradictory but nonetheless possibly true

reiterate.word_example: But despite these notable exceptions, I must honestly  reiterate that I have been disappointed with the church.
reiterate.word_definition: to say, state, or perform again

assembly.word_description: Synonyms include meeting or gathering in public.
assembly.word_example: But such an ordinance becomes unjust when it is used to maintain segregation and to deny citizens the First Amendment privilege of peaceful  assembly and protest.

intimidated.word_example: They were too God intoxicated to be "astronomically  intimidated."
intimidated.word_definition: made scared or fearful as by threats

inextricably.word_example: Is organized religion too  inextricably bound to the status quo to save our nation and the world?
inextricably.word_definition: in a manner incapable of being disentangled or untied

defiance.word_example: Where were they when Governor Wallace gave a clarion call for  defiance and hatred?

affiliated.word_example: We have some eighty-five  affiliated organizations across the South, and one of them is the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights.

unfettered.word_definition: not bound by shackles and chains

conviction.word_definition: an unshakable belief in something without need for proof

tortuous.word_example: They have gone down the highways of the South on  tortuous rides for freedom.
tortuous.word_definition: marked by repeated turns and bends

clarion.word_description: George Wallace was the segregationist governor of Alabama.
clarion.word_example: Where were they when Governor Wallace gave a  clarion call for defiance and hatred?

ideology.word_example: And I am further convinced that if our white brothers dismiss as "rabble-rousers" and "outside agitators" those of us who employ nonviolent direct action, and if they refuse to support our nonviolent efforts, millions of Negroes will, out of frustration and despair, seek solace and security in black-nationalist  ideologies a development that would inevitably lead to a frightening racial nightmare.
ideology.word_definition: an orientation that characterizes the thinking of a group

gospel.word_description: Used as a proper noun, Christians generally refer to "The Gospel" as the story of Jesus.
gospel.word_example: Just as the prophets of the eighth century B.C. left their villages and carried their "thus saith the Lord" far beyond the boundaries of their home towns, and just as the Apostle Paul left his village of Tarsus and carried the  gospel of Jesus Christ to the far corners of the Greco-Roman world, so am I compelled to carry the  gospel of freedom beyond my own home town.

permit.word_example: For instance, I have been arrested on a charge of parading without a  permit.
permit.word_definition: a legal document giving official license to do something

existential.word_example: Is not segregation an  existential expression 'of man's tragic separation, his awful estrangement, his terrible sinfulness?
existential.word_definition: relating to or dealing with the state of being

provocation.word_example: I wish you had commended the Negro sit-inners and demonstrators of Birmingham for their sublime courage, their willingness to suffer and their amazing discipline in the midst of great  provocation.
provocation.word_definition: unfriendly behavior that causes anger or resentment

antidote.word_example: Unlike so many of their moderate brothers and sisters, they have recognized the urgency of the moment and sensed the need for powerful "action"  antidotes to combat the disease of segregation.
antidote.word_definition: a remedy that stops or controls the effects of a poison

integral.word_example: I am grateful to God that, through the influence of the Negro church, the way of nonviolence became an  integral part of our struggle.
integral.word_definition: existing as an essential constituent or characteristic

nonconformist.word_example: How we have blemished and scarred that body through social neglect and through fear of being  nonconformists.
nonconformist.word_definition: someone refusing to follow established standards of conduct

moral.word_description: Reinhold Niebuhr was a 20th Century American philosopher who preached about the need for realism in human thought. He once wrote, "Man's capacity for justice makes democracy possible; but man's inclination to injustice makes democracy necessary."
moral.word_example: Individuals may see the  moral light and voluntarily give up their unjust posture; but, as Reinhold Niebuhr has reminded us, groups tend to be more immoral than individuals.
moral.word_definition: concerned with principles of right and wrong

sanction.word_example: Par from being disturbed by the presence of the church, the power structure of the average community is consoled by the church's silent and often even vocal  sanction of things as they are.

languish.word_example: They have  languished in filthy, roach-infested jails, suffering the abuse and brutality of policemen who view them as "dirty nigger lovers."
languish.word_definition: lose vigor, health, or flesh, as through grief

concoct.word_description: Concoct often denotes something "made up" as an excuse.
concoct.word_example: But when you have seen vicious mobs lynch your mothers and fathers at will and drown your sisters and brothers at whim; when you have seen hate-filled policemen curse, kick and even kill your black brothers and sisters; when you see the vast majority of your twenty million Negro brothers smothering in an airtight cage of poverty in the midst of an affluent society; when you suddenly find your tongue twisted and your speech stammering as you seek to explain to your six-year-old daughter why she c

apostle.word_description: Dr. King, an ordained minister, was referring to the Apostle Paul who was one of Jesus' disciples.
apostle.word_example: Just as the prophets of the eighth century B.C. left their villages and carried their "thus saith the Lord" far beyond the boundaries of their home towns, and just as the  Apostle Paul left his village of Tarsus and carried the gospel of Jesus Christ to the far corners of the Greco-Roman world, so am I compelled to carry the gospel of freedom beyond my own home town.
apostle.word_definition: an ardent early supporter of a cause or reform

racism.word_example: Just as Socrates felt that it was necessary to create a tension in the mind so that individuals could rise from the bondage of myths and half-truths to the unfettered realm of creative analysis and objective appraisal, we must see the need for nonviolent gadflies to create the kind of tension in society that will help men rise from the dark depths of prejudice and  racism to the majestic heights of understanding and brotherhood.
racism.word_definition: discriminatory or abusive behavior towards another people

persecute.word_example: Was not Jesus an extremist for love: "Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and  persecute you."

scintillating.word_example: Let us all hope that the dark clouds of racial prejudice will soon pass away and the deep fog of misunderstanding will be lifted from our fear-drenched communities, and in some not too distant tomorrow the radiant stars of love and brotherhood will shine over our great nation with all their  scintillating beauty.
scintillating.word_definition: marked by high spirits or excitement

privilege.word_example: Lamentably, it is an historical fact that  privileged groups seldom give up their  privileges voluntarily.
privilege.word_definition: a special advantage or benefit not enjoyed by all

catapult.word_example: When I was suddenly  catapulted into the leadership of the bus protest in Montgomery, Alabama, a few years ago, I felt we would be supported by the white church felt that the white ministers, priests and rabbis of the South would be among our strongest allies.

commissioner.word_description: Birmingham's Commissioner for Public Safety Eugene "Bull" Connor was in charge of the fire and police departments. He ordered the use of fire hoses and police dogs against non-violent protestors including women and children.
commissioner.word_example: When we discovered that the  Commissioner of Public Safety, Eugene "Bull" Connor, had piled up enough votes to be in the run-off we decided again to postpone action until the day after the run-off so that the demonstrations could not be used to cloud the issues.

prophetic.word_example: Some---such as Ralph McGill, Lillian Smith, Harry Golden, James McBride Dabbs, Ann Braden and Sarah Patton Boyle---have written about our struggle in eloquent and  prophetic terms.
prophetic.word_definition: foretelling events as if by supernatural intervention

vitality.word_example: For more than two centuries our forebears labored in this country without wages; they made cotton king; they built the homes of their masters while suffering gross injustice and shameful humiliation-and yet out of a bottomless  vitality they continued to thrive and develop.
vitality.word_definition: a healthy capacity for vigorous activity

admonish.word_example: I have heard numerous southern religious leaders  admonish their worshipers to comply with a desegregation decision because it is the law, but I have longed to hear white ministers declare: "Follow this decree because integration is morally right and because the Negro is your brother."
admonish.word_definition: scold or reprimand; take to task

segregation.word_example: Frankly, I have yet to engage in a direct-action campaign that was "well timed" in the view of those who have not suffered unduly from the disease of  segregation.
segregation.word_definition: a social system with separate facilities for minority groups

humiliate.word_description: Under the South's system of Jim Crow Laws most public businesses were segregated. This meant that stores, restaurants or other businesses posted signs that might read, "Whites Only" or "Negroes Must Use Back Door." Synonyms include "embarrass" and "degrade"
humiliate.word_example: In the course of the negotiations, certain promises were made by the merchants --- for example, to remove the stores  humiliating racial signs.

ineffectual.word_example: So often the contemporary church is a weak,  ineffectual voice with an uncertain sound.

devious.word_example: Throughout Alabama all sorts of  devious methods are used to prevent Negroes from becoming registered voters, and there are some counties in which, even though Negroes constitute a majority of the population, not a single Negro is registered.

sublime.word_example: I wish you had commended the Negro sit-inners and demonstrators of Birmingham for their  sublime courage, their willingness to suffer and their amazing discipline in the midst of great provocation.

diligently.word_example: Since we so  diligently urge people to obey the Supreme Court's decision of 1954 outlawing segregation in the public schools, at first glance it may seem rather paradoxical for us consciously to break laws.

cognizant.word_description: "Aware of" is often used as a synonym for "cognizant of"
cognizant.word_example: Moreover, I am  cognizant of the interrelatedness of all communities and states.
cognizant.word_definition: having or showing knowledge or understanding or realization

dialogue.word_example: Too long has our beloved Southland been bogged down in a tragic effort to live in monologue rather than  dialogue.
dialogue.word_definition: a discussion intended to produce an agreement

degenerate.word_example: But when you have seen vicious mobs lynch your mothers and fathers at will and drown your sisters and brothers at whim; when you have seen hate-filled policemen curse, kick and even kill your black brothers and sisters; when you see the vast majority of your twenty million Negro brothers smothering in an airtight cage of poverty in the midst of an affluent society; when you suddenly find your tongue twisted and your speech stammering as you seek to explain to your six-year-old daughter why she c

formulation.word_example: One day the South will know that when these disinherited children of God sat down at lunch counters, they were in reality standing up for what is best in the American dream and for the most sacred values in our Judaeo-Christian heritage, thereby bringing our nation back to those great wells of democracy which were dug deep by the founding fathers in their  formulation of the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.
formulation.word_definition: the act of inventing or contriving an idea or explanation

obnoxious.word_description: Synonyms include offensive, loathsome, repugnant and hateful.
obnoxious.word_example: I had hoped that the white moderate would understand that the present tension in the South is a necessary phase of the transition from an  obnoxious negative peace, in which the Negro passively accepted his unjust plight, to a substantive and positive peace, in which all men will respect the dignity and worth of human personality.

abyss.word_example: There comes a time when the cup of endurance runs over, and men are no longer willing to be plunged into the  abyss of despair.

status quo.word_example: While Mr. Boutwell is a much more gentle person than Mr. Connor, they are both segregationists, dedicated to maintenance of the  status quo.

sanctimonious.word_example: In the midst of blatant injustices inflicted upon the Negro, I have watched white churchmen stand on the sideline and mouth pious. irrelevancies and  sanctimonious trivialities.

ordinance.word_example: Thus it is that I can urge men to obey the 1954 decision of the Supreme Court, for it is morally right; and I can urge them to disobey segregation  ordinances, for they are morally wrong.
ordinance.word_definition: a statute enacted by a city government

eloquent.word_example: Some---such as Ralph McGill, Lillian Smith, Harry Golden, James McBride Dabbs, Ann Braden and Sarah Patton Boyle---have written about our struggle in  eloquent and prophetic terms.

grapple.word_example: I am sure that none of you would want to rest content with the superficial kind of social analysis that deals merely with effects and does not  grapple with underlying causes.
grapple.word_definition: work hard to come to terms with or deal with something

harmony.word_example: An unjust law is a code that is out of  harmony with the moral law.

pilgrimage.word_example: So let him march; let him make prayer  pilgrimages to the city hall; let him go on freedom rides--and try to understand why he must do so.
pilgrimage.word_definition: a journey to a sacred place

incorrigible.word_example: Nourished by the Negro's frustration over the continued existence of racial discrimination, this movement is made up of people who have lost faith in America, who have absolutely repudiated Christianity, and who have concluded that the white man is an  incorrigible "devil."

deplore.word_example: You  deplore the demonstrations taking place in Birmingham.

minority.word_example: An unjust law is a code that a numerical or power majority group compels a  minority group to obey but does not make binding on itself.
minority.word_definition: a group of people who differ from a larger group

emulate.word_example: I have tried to stand between these two forces, saying that we need  emulate neither the "do-nothingism" of the complacent nor the hatred and despair of the black nationalist.
emulate.word_definition: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating

rabid.word_description: Rabid also refers to the disease rabies, thus when Dr. King writes about "rabid segregationists" he is symbolically comparing segregation to a disease that makes one go "mad" or crazy.
rabid.word_example: In no sense do I advocate evading or defying the law, as would the  rabid segregationist.
rabid.word_definition: marked by excessive enthusiasm for a cause or idea

complacent.word_example: I have tried to stand between these two forces, saying that we need emulate neither the "do-nothingism" of the  complacent nor the hatred and despair of the black nationalist.
complacent.word_definition: contented to a fault with oneself or one's actions

statute.word_description: Commonly a "statute" is a law passed by a state legislature.
statute.word_example: All segregation  statutes are unjust because segregation distorts the soul and damages the personality.
statute.word_definition: an act passed by a legislative body

inevitability.word_example: Human progress never rolls in on wheels of  inevitability; it comes through the tireless efforts of men willing to be co-workers with God, and without this 'hard work, time itself becomes an ally of the forces of social stagnation.

bondage.word_example: Just as Socrates felt that it was necessary to create a tension in the mind so that individuals could rise from the  bondage of myths and half-truths to the unfettered realm of creative analysis and objective appraisal, we must we see the need for nonviolent gadflies to create the kind of tension in society that will help men rise from the dark depths of prejudice and racism to the majestic heights of understanding and brotherhood.
bondage.word_definition: the state of being under the control of a force or influence

register.word_example: Throughout Alabama all sorts of devious methods are used to prevent Negroes from becoming  registered voters, and there are some counties in which, even though Negroes constitute a majority of the population, not a single Negro is  registered.

appalling.word_description: Synonyms include dreadful, frightful and shocking.
appalling.word_example: We will have to repent in this generation not merely for the hateful words and actions of the bad people but for the  appalling silence of the good people.

retaliate.word_example: We began a series of workshops on nonviolence, and we repeatedly asked ourselves : "Are you able to accept blows without  retaliating?"
retaliate.word_definition: make a counterattack and return like for like

Martin Luther King, Jr., \"Letter from a.list_detailed_description: In April 1963 Dr. King was arrested for leading a non-violent protest in Birmingham, Alabama. In a local newspaper a group of white clergymen criticized King. They acknowledged that injustices had been committed when local authorities used fire hoses, batons and police dogs on the demonstrators, but asserted that protest should only be done through the courts. From his jail cell King responded. His letter justifies the use of non-violent protest to fight unjust laws.

defend.word_example: An act for granting and applying certain stamp duties, and other duties, in the British colonies and plantations in America, towards further defraying the expences of  defending, protecting, and securing the same; and for amending such parts of the several acts of parliament relating to the trade and revenues of the said colonies and plantations, as direct the manner of determining and recovering the penalties and forfeitures therein mentioned.

Stamp Act (1765).list_detailed_description: The Stamp Act was an act passed by the British Parliament in 1765 in order to collect revenue in the American colonies. The act upset many colonists, since it was passed without the colonists' consent and thus there were widespread protests. The protests were so effective that the tax was never collected in any meaningful way.
